headline.main: Medicare to Run Diet Experiment for Critically Ill

docs.abstract: Medicare program, in first-even experiment on critically ill elderly people, will undertake larges-scale test of low-fat diet and exercise program developed by Dr Dean Ornish, who for more than 20 years has studied whether changes in diet and daily activities can reverse coronary heart disease; Ornish program is a radical one, combining extremely low-fat, vegetarian diet with exercise, meditation and smoking cessation; enrollment of volunteers in Medicare experiment starts on April 10; nutrition and exercise experiment is designed to determine whether drastic changes in lifestyle and eating habits can prevent need for angioplasty and heart bypass surgery; photos (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Eva Hebenstreit remembers a trip to Israel in January 1986, when her 71-year-old husband, Werner, could not get across the street before the light changed. ''He was a cripple,'' said Mrs. Hebenstreit. ''A permanent coronary cripple.''
docs.snippet: Eva Hebenstreit remembers a trip to Israel in January 1986, when her 71-year-old husband, Werner, could not get across the street before the light changed.    ''He was a cripple,'' said Mrs. Hebenstreit. ''A permanent coronary cripple.''

headline.main: Some Say 'Play Ball.' He Says 'Open Wide.'

docs.abstract: Dr John Wisniewski, New Jersey dentist and avid baseball fan, attends Atlanta Braves spring training as volunteer examining players for mouth lesions or other signs of potential cancer caused by chewing tobacco; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: THE grassy outfield expanses and dusty ocher basepaths of the nation's ballparks seem light years from the small gray-and-maroon paper-strewn office of Dr. John Wisniewskion on the campus of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey here. But baseball is never far from the thoughts of this associate professor of dentistry. Last month, as he has for the past seven seasons, Dr. Wisniewski spent part of spring training with the Atlanta Braves at its Walt Disney World camp. But the avid baseball fan wasn't there for a fantasy vacation or to gawk at the athletes who have diverted his loyalties from his boyhood favorites, the Yankees and the Mets. Though he admits the annual outing is a happy marriage of his passions for baseball and dentistry, he flew to Florida to continue his volunteer work against one of the less savory aspects of the national pasttime -- the dipping and chewing of smokeless tobacco.
docs.snippet: THE grassy outfield expanses and dusty ocher basepaths of the nation's ballparks seem light years from the small gray-and-maroon paper-strewn office of Dr. John Wisniewskion on the campus of the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey...
